Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery alabastron or olpe; exterior: decoration consisting of five rows of double incised glazed black scales with central dots, some in added white and others in added red.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Venit (1988, p. 62, no. 220), the sherd probably comes from a large flat-bottomed aryballos. Double incised scales are more commonly found on olpai and large alabastra. The sherd likely belongs to the Scale Pattern Group.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 62, pl. 50, no. 220)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 218)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.282) (phase 3)
